title: New Street and Grand Central: A business risk?
text:
By ITV News Central's Business Correspondent, Mark Gough
Behind the shiny new façade of Grand Central, which stands above New Street station, businesses are risking millions of pounds.
The vast size of Grand Central Credit: ITV News Central It's a huge risk, but they believe it's a calculated risk, because it will be five times larger than Euston station in London, with 62 shops and restaurants.
On a busy day, the old New Street station saw a quarter of a million people. And it is those people with cash in their pockets that the Grand Central shops and restaurants are interested in. Investing in Birmingham is clearly a bright idea.
One of the restaurants opening up in Grand Central Credit: ITV News Central There are several businesses that were going to invest a lot of money in other cities - northern powerhouses - and they decided to come to Birmingham. There is one business that was going to invest elsewhere that has decided to put it's £20million into the city rather than somewhere else, and I think it's an extremely wise decision.
They came and visited the site, they walked round the city, they understand what we're trying to do with the council and all the other businesses working together to create a fantastic environment.
– Jonathan Cheetham, General Manager of Grand Central Omar Allibhoy, a chef from Madrid in Spain, and his business partners, have spent three quarters of a million pounds bringing tapas to Birmingham.
Omar Allibhoy prepares for opening later this week Credit: ITV News Central I felt there was a great opportunity because people are very knowledgable about their food in Birmingham and it's becoming a very exciting city. All my restaurants are in London, this is my first venture outside it and I feel that Birmingham is the place to be.
– Omar Allibhoy A big decider is the John Lewis factor - build one and they will come - shoppers and other shops that is.
Nishil Thakrar's company is moving into Grand Central Credit: ITV News Central Nishil Thakrar and his dad, from Birmingham, have been selling their designer clothes online for years, but now they are taking the plunge with their first shop.
Play video An established brand, which will have its products in John Lewis, has also opted to have a standalone store at Grand Central.
Joules saw early that shops in stations are a good idea after opening up at London St Pancras.
Play video With Birmingham New Street's new capacity of 300,000 people per day, all the businesses hope that will mean enough trade to make their risks pay off.
